docs.abstract: Referendums include issues from Medicaid expansion to abortion, dialysis costs to indoor vaping, and much more.
docs.snippet: Referendums include issues from Medicaid expansion to abortion, dialysis costs to indoor vaping, and much more.
docs.lead_paragraph: Health care has been a dominant issue on the campaign trail this fall, with voters particularly worried about continuing insurance protections for people with pre-existing medical conditions. But on Election Day, they will decide a number of other important health care questions for their states through ballot initiatives.

headline.main: It’s Not Just Pre-Existing Conditions. Voters Weigh Many Health Issues on State Ballots
headline.print_headline: Voters to Weigh Vaping, Soda Taxes and More

byline.original: By Abby Goodnough and Jan Hoffman

headline.main: Shorting Cannabis Stocks Is Getting Costly

docs.abstract: Coke, PepsiCo and other big beverage companies are the unseen forces (and funders) behind ballot initiatives that would ban taxes on food sales.
docs.snippet: Coke, PepsiCo and other big beverage companies are the unseen forces (and funders) behind ballot initiatives that would ban taxes on food sales.
docs.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Standing in a supermarket produce aisle, her face shadowed with dread, the middle-aged woman speaks directly to the camera and makes a plea for common decency.

headline.main: Where ‘Yes! To Affordable Groceries’ Really Means No to a Soda Tax
headline.print_headline: When Yes Really Means No To a Tax on Sugary Drinks

docs.abstract: A sign showing Coca-Cola’s jolly Santa Claus with a bottle of Coke in each hand wasn’t what it appeared to be. It drew a boycott online, and soda brands into politics.
docs.snippet: A sign showing Coca-Cola’s jolly Santa Claus with a bottle of Coke in each hand wasn’t what it appeared to be. It drew a boycott online, and soda brands into politics.
docs.lead_paragraph: As Coca-Cola rolled out its seasonal advertising campaign in Germany, drivers on a busy street in Berlin spotted what seemed to be a familiar billboard last week.

headline.main: German Activists Use Coca-Cola, and Santa Claus, to Denounce the Far Right

docs.abstract: The creators of the hit Netflix series wrote the failed beverage into the coming season as part of a big marketing push. With memories of a 1985 backlash faded, Coca-Cola dug out the old recipe.
docs.snippet: The creators of the hit Netflix series wrote the failed beverage into the coming season as part of a big marketing push. With memories of a 1985 backlash faded, Coca-Cola dug out the old recipe.
docs.lead_paragraph: New Coke, the soft drink that drew a nationwide backlash in 1985, is back. And the credit, or blame, for the return of Coca-Cola’s greatest folly goes to Netflix.

headline.main: New Coke Was a Debacle. It’s Coming Back. Blame ‘Stranger Things.’
headline.print_headline: New Coke Was a Debacle. It’s Coming Back. Blame Netflix.

docs.abstract: In Eastern Europe, right-wing nationalists have focused their wrath on L.G.B.T. people, who they say are forcing immoral ways on their countries.
docs.snippet: In Eastern Europe, right-wing nationalists have focused their wrath on L.G.B.T. people, who they say are forcing immoral ways on their countries.
docs.lead_paragraph: WARSAW — By the standards of Western advertising, Coca-Cola’s billboard campaign in Hungary was pretty tame.

headline.main: Coke Ad Riles Hungary Conservatives, Part of Larger Gay Rights Battle
headline.print_headline: Hungary’s Anti-Gay Conservatives Are Riled by Coke Campaign

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

docs.abstract: Misleading marketing and labeling may confuse parents about the health value of many juices, a new report finds.
docs.snippet: Misleading marketing and labeling may confuse parents about the health value of many juices, a new report finds.
docs.lead_paragraph: Slave to your sweet tooth? Researchers say the predilection for sweetened drinks — a major driver of the nation’s obesity crisis — begins in childhood. That’s one reason health experts recommend children under 2 never be given fruit juice. When it comes to children 2 to 18, the American Academy of Pediatrics recommends a daily limit of 25 grams of sugar, or six teaspoons.

headline.main: How Children Get Hooked on Sugary Drinks
headline.print_headline: How Children Are Getting Hooked on Sugary Drinks

docs.abstract: The files, which hadn't previously been disclosed, show a closer relationship between the E.P.A. and J. Steven Hart, the lobbyist husband of Mr. Pruitt's landlord, than earlier acknowledged.
docs.snippet: The files, which hadn't previously been disclosed, show a closer relationship between the E.P.A. and J. Steven Hart, the lobbyist husband of Mr. Pruitt's landlord, than earlier acknowledged.
docs.lead_paragraph: Scott Pruitt, the head of the Environmental Protection Agency, discussed hiring a friend of a lobbyist family that owned a condominium he was renting for $50 a night, newly released emails suggest. The files also show communications involving the lobbyist’s client interests that have not previously been disclosed, suggesting a closer relationship between the  lobbyist, J. Steven Hart, and the agency than previously known.

headline.main: New Emails Suggest Scott Pruitt Discussed Hiring a Friend of Lobbyist Landlord
headline.print_headline: Pruitt and Lobbyist Had Close Ties, Emails Suggest

byline.original: By Lisa Friedman and Hiroko Tabuchi

docs.abstract: Scandals involving the host, Russia and soccer’s governing body, FIFA, offer opportunities for Chinese soft-power ambitions.
docs.snippet: Scandals involving the host, Russia and soccer’s governing body, FIFA, offer opportunities for Chinese soft-power ambitions.
docs.lead_paragraph: When the World Cup opens in Moscow on June 14, soccer fans may notice something out of the ordinary. Alongside the slick ad campaigns for famous global brands — Visa, Adidas, Coca-Cola — there will be a proliferation of pitches from obscure companies with names like Mengniu, Vivo and Wanda. These newly minted World Cup sponsors aren’t selling much that is related to soccer; these three, for example, trade in dairy products, electric scooters and movie theaters. They all come from a country, moreover, whose national team has never scored a single World Cup goal and is not among the 32 qualifying teams this year, but which still sees itself as the future of soccer: China.

headline.main: China Won’t Play in This World Cup. It Still Hopes to Profit.
headline.print_headline: China Won’t Play in This World Cup. It Still Hopes to Profit.

docs.abstract: Lower supplies of the gas mean that beer loses its fizz and some meat can’t be packaged. That could affect the supply of some staples of British summers.
docs.snippet: Lower supplies of the gas mean that beer loses its fizz and some meat can’t be packaged. That could affect the supply of some staples of British summers.
docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Beer, barbecues and crumpets, three staples of life in Britain as it enjoys an unusually warm summer, may soon experience shortages as the country faces an unexpected shortfall — of carbon dioxide.

headline.main: U.K. Fears for Its Beer and Crumpets. Blame a Carbon Dioxide Shortage.
headline.print_headline: Gas Shortage Threatens to Flatten British Staples
